case_vignette: A 30-year-old man is brought into the emergency room for complaints of acute onset chest pain and shortness of breath. He has a history of mental retardation and lives at home with his adoptive parents. His parents inform you that he has not seen a doctor since he was adopted as child and that he currently takes no medications. The patient’s temperature is 99.1°F (37.3°C),pulse is 108/min, blood pressure is 125/70 mmHg, respirations are 25/min, and oxygen saturation is 92% on 2L nasal canula. Physical exam is notable for a tall, thin individual with high-arched feet and mild pectus excavatum. There is mild asymmetry in the lower extremities with discomfort to dorsiflexion of the larger leg. Lung auscultation reveals no abnormalities.
question: What is the next step in the diagnosis of this patient’s underlying disorder?

Okay, that's helpful to know. Based on what you've told me, I would like to perform a quick physical examination to help determine the cause of your symptoms. May I please listen to your heart with a stethoscope?

Great, thank you. Based on the listening, I would like to perform a few more tests to help confirm the diagnosis. I will need to take your blood pressure and perform an electrocardiogram (ECG) to check for any abnormal heart rhythms. Can you please roll up your sleeve and let me take your blood pressure? Okay, I've rolled up my sleeve, and I'll lie down on the examination table for the ECG.

Great, thank you. I will now perform the ECG. This will only take a few minutes.

While I perform the ECG, can you please tell me if you have any other symptoms such as dizziness, lightheadedness, or shortness of breath? And have you noticed any other unusual symptoms such as chest pain or discomfort?
I am already experiencing shortness of breath and chest pain, but no dizziness or lightheadedness.

Thank you for letting me know. Based on the symptoms you've described, I suspect that you may be experiencing a heart attack. I will need to call for emergency medical services to transport you to the hospital immediately.

In the meantime, I will perform an electrocardiogram (ECG) to confirm the diagnosis and determine the extent of the damage to your heart. I will also administer aspirin to help thin your blood and reduce the risk of further damage to your heart.

Please try to remain calm and still while I perform the ECG and administer the aspirin. I will do my best to make sure you are comfortable and safe throughout the process.

I see. It's important to understand that you are not alone in this situation. Many people have mental retardation and live fulfilling lives with the support of their families and loved ones.

As a doctor, I want to make sure that you receive the appropriate medical care and attention. However, I also understand that your mental retardation may affect your ability to communicate and understand medical information.

Also, have you experienced any other medical problems or symptoms recently? It's important for me to have a complete understanding of your overall health.
I communicate well with my adoptive parents, but the vignette does not provide details about my communication abilities or any other recent medical problems or symptoms.

I see. In that case, based on the information provided in the vignette, I will proceed with the examination and perform an electrocardiogram (ECG) to check for any abnormal heart rhythms or damage to your heart muscle.

Can you please roll up your sleeve and prepare for the ECG? I will need to place electrodes on your skin to record the electrical activity of your heart. The test is painless and should only take a few minutes.

While I perform the ECG, can you tell me more about your daily activities and any recent changes in your routine? This information can help me understand your overall health and identify any potential causes of your symptoms.
I haven't had any recent changes in my daily activities or routine.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on the information provided, I believe it's important to rule out any cardiac causes for your symptoms. I will proceed with the ECG and ask you to hold your breath and move your arms and legs as I perform the test. This will help me get a clearer picture of your heart's electrical activity.

Also, I would like to ask you some questions about your medical history and any medications you are currently taking. This information will help me better understand your overall health and make an accurate diagnosis.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've got a sudden chest pain and I'm feeling short of breath.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Can you tell me how long have you been experiencing this chest pain and shortness of breath? And do you have any history of heart disease or other medical conditions?
I just started feeling the chest pain and shortness of breath today, and I don't have any known history of heart disease or other medical conditions.

Thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to ask you a few more questions to help narrow down the possible causes.

Can you tell me if you have any allergies or if you have recently traveled anywhere? And have you noticed any other symptoms such as fever, nausea, or vomiting?
I'm not aware of any allergies, I haven't traveled recently, and I haven't had a fever, nausea, or vomiting.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to ask you a few more questions to help determine the cause of your chest pain and shortness of breath.

Can you tell me if you have a history of smoking or if you are currently a smoker? And have you noticed any other symptoms such as chest tightness, pain in the arms or jaw, or difficulty breathing when lying down?
No, I don't smoke, and I haven't noticed chest tightness, pain in the arms or jaw, or difficulty breathing when lying down.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to ask you a few more questions to help determine the cause of your chest pain and shortness of breath.

Can you tell me if you have any history of heart problems in your family? Have you noticed any other symptoms such as palpitations, dizziness, or fatigue? And have you recently experienced any stress or anxiety?
I don't know of any heart problems in my family, and I haven't had palpitations, dizziness, or fatigue, nor have I been particularly stressed or anxious recently.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms and medical history, I would like to consider a few possible causes for your chest pain and shortness of breath.

One possibility is that you may be experiencing a heart attack or unstable angina. This can occur when the blood flow to the heart is blocked, causing damage to the heart muscle. Other possible causes include coronary artery disease, pulmonary embolism, and pneumonia.

I would like to recommend that you visit an emergency room or see a cardiologist as soon as possible for further evaluation and treatment. They will be able to perform tests such as an electrocardiogram (ECG), blood tests, and imaging studies to determine the cause of your symptoms and provide appropriate treatment.

Final diagnosis: Unstable angina or heart attack.

Next, I would like to perform some diagnostic tests, such as an electrocardiogram (ECG) or a stress test, to check for any abnormalities in your heart rhythm or function. I may also recommend a chest X-ray or a computed tomography (CT) scan to rule out any other conditions that may be causing your symptoms.

If the results of these tests are normal, I may recommend further testing, such as a cardiac MRI or a cardiac catheterization, to get a more detailed look at your heart and its function.
